metadata.publisher: UK Department of Energy & Climate Change

scope.narrative: This will cover all of the UK's Department of Energy & Climate Change's share of the £2.9 billion International Climate Fund (ICF). The Department of Energy & Climate Change's allocation is £1 billion (34%) from 1 April 2011 to 31 March 2015. The ICF will be Official Development Assistance (ODA) and will be spent in line with OECD Development Assistance Committee guidelines. The outstanding £1.9 billion is split between two departments: The Department for International Development's allocation is £1.8 billion. The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs's allocation is £100 million.

publication-timetable.narrative: DECC plans to first publish IATI information in September 2012. DECC started publishing project documents on our website (http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/tackling/international/icf/icf.aspx) from May 2012 and will continue to do so as project documents (business cases, annual reviews, evaluation studies) become available.

publication-frequency.narrative: DECC will submit IATI data quarterly with the most up-to-date information available.

publication-lifecycle.narrative: Project data will be published following Ministerial approval.

data-quality.narrative: The information provided will be operational data. Audited annual accounts for the Department (including ICF expenditure) are prepared separately and published on our website (http://www.decc.gov.uk/en/content/cms/about/our_goals/annual_reports/annual_reports.aspx).

approach.narrative: The DECC ICF team will lead on implementing and managing IATI commitments. Existing systems will be modified to meet IATI commitments.

exclusions.narrative:
For aid projects the assumption will be of automatic disclosure of any information that UK Government has committed to publish, however a small number of exclusions apply to these in order not to do harm to UK Government’s work or staff. These are based on the key principles of the UK’s Freedom of Information Act and are as follows:
i. International relations: Information that may harm UK Government’s relations with other governments or institutions. ii. Security and safety: Information that may pose a risk to the security or safety of any individual, including UK Government staff, contractors and beneficiaries. iii. Personal information: Information that intrudes on the privacy of a person or could contravene confidentiality. iv. Commercially sensitive information: Information that does harm to UK Government’s or UK Government’s partners or suppliers commercial interests. v. Information that is exempt from disclosure under other policies or regulations

license.narrative: When publishing our data on the web DECC is obliged to follow the guidance outlined by the UK National Archives. DECC will allow use and reuse of the information free of charge in any format or medium, under the terms of the Open Government Licence. This requires that information is attributed to the UK government. Where DECC has identified any third party copyright material, permission will need to be obtained from the copyright holders.

activity-multilevel.narrative: DECC publishes at the project level. For policy definition purposes, a project refers to all DECC-funded interventions, whether bilateral, core contributions to multilaterals, or agreements with non-governmental organisations etc. For technical definition purposes, projects are umbrella records that may encapsulate several components. Some data elements, project purpose, documents, risk and scoring are stored at project level.

segmentation.narrative: Several projects are not specific to one country and data will be published at the project level and geographic coverage will be clearly identified.

user-interface.narrative: IATI data will be accessible through the DECC website.
